texts.shortText:
Diatoms are a very important group of typically single-celled, photosynthetic, planktonic organisms that together make up a significant proportion of the earth’s biomass. They are best known for possessing hard silica cases called ‘frustules’. Most species are solitary, but some join together to form colonial structures of various shapes, including chains ribbons, fans, stars, or even larger colonies that resemble seaweeds.

In this species the cells are rectangular and pillow-shaped and may occur singly or in chains of two to a few attached cells. The blooms form brown, slick-like scums on the water surface and are often stranded as foam-like deposits. Blooms are characteristic of long, dissipative beaches subject to strong wave action.
Cells typically only about 10-20 microns broad and 15-60 microns long.

Global: Australia, New Zealand and South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay.

The blooms are restricted to long, unbroken beaches with broad dissipative surf zones (in our area notably Muizenberg Beach) where they form brown patches that are often mistaken as pollution.

The blooms show a distinct diurnal pattern, cells emerging from the sand in the morning and entering the water column, where they attach to bubbles and form a surface foam. In the late aftenoon, they drop out of the foam and sink back to the botton, where they enter the sand. This behaviour also traps the blooms within the surf zone, as cells tend to get pushed shorewards by the breaking waves during the day and returned into the surf zone by rip currents when they sink back to the bottom in the afternoon.

The blooms are important primary producers on such beaches and sustain a whole community of associated animals.
Easy to distinguish by virtue of the unusual habitat and bloom-forming behaviour.

Kruger, I & Wilson, EG (1984). Morphology and affiliation of the centric diatom Anaulus birostratus (Grunow) Grunow from South Africa. South African Journal of Marine Science, 2(1), 163-194.

Talbot, MMB & Bate, GC (1986). Diel periodicities in cell characteristics of the surfzone diatom Anaulus birostratus: their role in the dynamics of cell patches. Marine Ecology Progress Series, 32, 81-89.

Talbot, MMB & Bate, GC (1988). The use of false buoyancies by the surf diatom Anaulus birostratus in the formation and decay of cell patches. Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science, 26(2), 155-167.
